intro: Thamnocalamus ringala, commonly known as the golden bamboo, is a species of grass native to Southeast Asia. It is characterized by its tall, slender stalks and dense, golden-green foliage. The plant belongs to the grass family Poaceae and is often found in moist, shaded environments. Its rhizomes form a dense network that helps stabilize soil and prevent erosion. Due to its ornamental value and ecological benefits, it is cultivated in gardens and used in traditional medicine.
